intro: Isolepis pumilo, commonly known as the dwarf sedge, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in the northern hemisphere. It is a member of the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, rushes, and grasses. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, forming dense clumps with narrow, grass-like leaves. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are arranged in spikelets, and it produces tiny, wind-dispersed seeds. Isolepis pumilo plays an important role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems and providing habitat for various aquatic organisms.
